0.did_you_know: No one knows where the Martini really comes from!
0.short_descript: The Classic Martini is known for its elegance and simplicity, combining gin and dry vermouth for a crisp, botanical flavor. Garnished with a lemon twist, it offers a smooth and zesty finish. Ideal if you prefer timeless sophistication.
0.description: There’s a timeless elegance to the classic martini, known for its crisp and clear sophistication. To master the art of mixing this iconic cocktail, we will focus on the traditional preparation of the Classic Martini. The process is straightforward, following the same meticulous steps used across martini variations, allowing you to quickly refer to the definitive recipe for this quintessentially smooth, gin-and-vermouth blend.

gin.info: The spirit foundation of the Classic Martini, offering botanical notes that are crisp and aromatic.

dry vermouth.info: Adds a subtle herbal complexity and balances the gin's robust flavor.

lemon twist.info: Garnish enhances the martini with a zesty aroma and a hint of citrus elegance.

cocktail shaker.info: Martinis must be shaken! Any kind of cocktail shaker will work for this drink.

ice.info: For shaking the drink and for putting in the final drink! Don’t forget the ice!

step_details: Chill martini glass by either leaving the glass in the freezer for at least 10 minutes prior to serving or by filling the glass with ice and water, letting sit for 2-3 minutes, and dumping out the ice and water.
Fill your shaker ½ of the way with ice.
Add the gin and dry vermouth into a mixing glass with ice
Firmly grip the stirring spoon with one hand and place it in the mixing glass filled with ingredients.
Stir in a smooth, circular motion to chill and dilute the mixture without creating bubbles.
Continue stirring until the outside of the mixing glass feels cold to the touch.
Once adequately stirred, separate the spoon from the glass and prepare to strain the cocktail into a chilled martini glass.
Strain the martini and pour into the glass (might require extra strainer tool if using a Boston shaker).
Garnish your glass with your lemon twist!

1.did_you_know: It's inspiration came from the candy shop
1.short_descript: The Lemon Drop Martini is a lively blend of vodka, lemon juice, and triple sec. Its tart yet sweet flavor profile, accented by a sugared rim and lemon garnish, makes it perfect for those seeking a refreshing, bright cocktail.
1.description: There are endless martini recipes with a sweet flavor profile. To become familiar with crafting recipes and ordering margaritas in the sweet taste group, we will be learning how to make a Lemon Drop Martini. Since most martinis have the same steps, you can also skip straight to the stand-alone recipe for the Lemon Drop Martini.

lemon juice.info: It would not be a lemon drop martini without lemon juice! Any will work for this recipe!

vodka.info: Vodka is the key ingredient! Any vodka will work for this recipe!

sugar.info: Add some sweetness into your drink!

lemon slice.info: For a garnish to top it off, don't forget a thin slice of lemon!

cocktail shaker.info: Martinis must be shaken! Any kind of cocktail shaker will work for this drink.

triple sec.info: Any kind of Triple Sec or Orange Liqueur will work! We recommend using Cointreau.

ice.info: For shaking the drink and for putting in the final drink! Don’t forget the ice!

step_details: Chill martini glass by either leaving the glass in the freezer for at least 10 minutes prior to serving or by filling the glass with ice and water, letting sit for 2-3 minutes, and dumping out the ice and water.
Fill your shaker ½ of the way with ice.
Pour the vodka, triple sec, lemon juice and sugar into the cocktail shaker.
Close the shaker either with a lid or smaller tin.
Firmly grip the shaker with both hands – one hand on the top and one hand on the bottom.
Shake in a circular motion until the shaker produces condensation.
Separate the two shaking units once done.
Run the lemon twist around the edge of the chilled martini glass.
Slowly turn the glass in a small amount of sugar for a coated rim.
Strain the martini and pour into the glass (might require extra strainer tool if using a Boston shaker).
Garnish with a lemon twist!

2.did_you_know: Created in 1983 by London bartender Dick Bradsell at Fred’s Club, the Espresso Martini was inspired by a model's request for a drink that would 'wake me up and mess me up.'
2.short_descript: The Espresso Martini delivers a bold mix of vodka, coffee liqueur, and freshly brewed espresso. Topped with coffee beans for aroma, it's an ideal choice if you enjoy a smooth cocktail with a rich coffee flavor.
2.description: There's a rich array of martini recipes with a robust, coffee-inspired twist. To explore the art of crafting and enjoying these caffeinated delights, we'll delve into the making of the Espresso Martini. As with many martinis, the preparation steps are quite similar, allowing you to easily jump to the standalone recipe for this velvety, coffee-flavored cocktail.

coffee liqueur.info: Enhances the cocktail with a rich, caramel sweetness.

vodka.info: Vodka is the key ingredient! Any vodka will work for this recipe!

brewed espresso.info: Provides a fresh, bold coffee flavor foundation.

simple syrup.info: Adds a touch of sweetness to balance the bold flavors.

coffee beans.info: Used as a garnish to add aroma and a decorative touch!

ice.info: For shaking the drink and for putting in the final drink! Don’t forget the ice!

cocktail shaker.info: Martinis must be shaken! Any kind of cocktail shaker will work for this drink.

step_details: Brew the coffee then pour into a bowl to cool quickly.
Fill your shaker ½ of the way with ice.
Pour the cooled coffee, vodka and simple syrup into the cocktail shaker.
Next, add the coffee liqueur.
Close the shaker either with a lid or smaller tin.
Firmly grip the shaker with both hands – one hand on the top and one hand on the bottom.
Shake in a circular motion until the shaker produces condensation.
Separate the two shaking units once done.
Strain the martini and pour into the glass (might require extra strainer tool if using a Boston shaker).
Finish off with the coffee beans garnish!
